Example 1:
An electrostatic generator, or electrostatic machine, is an electromechanical generator that produces static electricity, or electricity at high voltage and low continuous current. The knowledge of static electricity dates back to the earliest civilizations, but for millennia it remained merely an interesting and mystifying phenomenon, without a theory to explain its behavior and often confused with magnetism. By the end of the 17th Century, researchers had developed practical means of generating electricity by friction, but the development of electrostatic machines did not begin in earnest until the 18th century, when they became fundamental instruments in the studies about the new science of electricity. Electrostatic generators operate by using manual (or other) power to transform mechanical work into electric energy. Electrostatic generators develop electrostatic charges of opposite signs rendered to two conductors, using only electric forces, and work by using moving plates, drums, or belts to carry electric charge to a high potential electrode. The charge is generated by one of two methods: either the triboelectric effect (friction) or electrostatic induction.

Prehistory refers to the period of human existence before written records. The study of prehistory is a subfield of archaeology and anthropology. The term 'prehistory' refers to the period of time before written records were kept. This period spans from the emergence of the first humans to the invention of writing. Prehistory can be divided into three periods: the Paleolithic, Mesolithic, and Neolithic. The Paleolithic period is characterized by the use of tools made from stone and the hunting and gathering of food. The Mesolithic period saw the introduction of more sophisticated tools and the development of early agriculture. The Neolithic period marks the beginning of settled agriculture and the rise of complex societies. This period laid the foundation for modern civilizations. The invention of writing marked the end of prehistory and the beginning of recorded history.

Prehistory is a period of time before recorded history, which includes the entirety of human history before the invention of writing systems. The knowledge of prehistory has been pieced together from archaeological evidence, such as artifacts, fossils, and landscapes. The prehistoric period can be divided into three main categories: the Paleolithic, Mesolithic, and Neolithic. The Paleolithic period, also known as the Old Stone Age, is the earliest period of human history, marked by the use of stone tools and the development of early human societies. This period is characterized by the discovery of fire and the control of tools. The Mesolithic and Neolithic periods are marked by the development of more complex societies and the introduction of agriculture. The study of prehistory provides valuable insights into the evolution of human societies and the development of complex cultures.

By the end of the 17th Century, researchers had developed practical means of generating electricity by friction, but the development of electrostatic machines did not begin in earnest until the 18th century, when they became fundamental instruments in the studies about the new science of electricity. Electrostatic generators operate by using manual (or other) power to transform mechanical work into electric energy. Electrostatic generators develop electrostatic charges of opposite signs rendered to two conductors, using only electric forces, and work by using moving plates, drums, or belts to carry electric charge to a high potential electrode. The charge is generated by one of two methods: either the triboelectric effect (friction) or electrostatic induction.

Example 2:
It is easy to prove that the most economical way of reducing addition to counting similar quantities is by the binary arithmetic of Leibnitz, which appears in an altered dress, with most of the zero signs suppressed, in the example below. Opposite each number in the usual figures is here set the same according to a scheme in which the signs of powers of two repeat themselves in periods of four; a very small circle, like a degree mark, being used to express any fourth power in the series; a long loop, like a narrow 0, any square not a fourth power; a curve upward and to the right, like a phonographic l, any double fourth power; and a curve to the right and downward, like a phonographic r, any half of a fourth power; with a vertical bar to denote the absence of three successive powers not fourth powers.

Prehistory is the period of human history and culture before written records were kept. This period is also known as the "time before history". It began with the emergence of the first hominids, such as Australopithecus, in the Pliocene epoch of the Paleogene period, around 4 million years ago. The earliest humans, such as Homo habilis, were hunter-gatherers. Their societies were small, nomadic, and often had complex social hierarchies. The prehistoric period ended with the development of writing, which emerged independently in various parts of the world, around 5,500 years ago. This marked the beginning of recorded history.

Prehistory dates back to the earliest humans, preceding written records, and spans from the emergence of Homo sapiens to the advent of writing. It is a period of significant cultural, technological, and social evolution, with early humans developing tools, language, and complex societies. The study of prehistory relies on archaeological and anthropological evidence, including artifacts, fossils, and genetic data. Researchers use this evidence to reconstruct the lives and cultures of early humans, providing valuable insights into human origins and development. Prehistory refers to the period of human history that occurred before written records were kept. This era is not well documented, and as a result, much of what is known about it is based on archaeological findings. The prehistoric era can be divided into several distinct periods, including the Paleolithic, Mesolithic, and Neolithic. These periods were characterized by significant changes in human culture and technology, including the development of tools, the domestication of plants and animals, and the emergence of settled agriculture. By studying prehistory, researchers can gain insight into the evolution of human society.  This helps them understand how modern humans developed.  By doing so, they can better understand the complex, interconnected world we live in.  In doing so, we can understand how we got here.   And, thus, we can better appreciate the world around us.
